Sunspots have the same temperature, chemical properties and luminosity as liquid iron.

If it looks, quacks and swims like a duck...

Sunspots are liquid iron.

The are the same temperature (~5,200° F)

Same chemical properties (highly magnetic and polarized positive and negative, like a magnet.)

Same luminosity (1/10,000 as bright as the surface despite being 1/2 as hot, which can only be explained because they are a different element and state of matter.)

Spectroscopy of solar flares (antimatter explosions) which always originate at sun spots show highly ionized iron (Fe +25).

Despite being hundreds of times denser than the Corona, they float in it for weeks or months. How?

Electromagnetism keeps them aloft. The same force pushes them (during polar reversal) from the radiative zone on either pole to the bottom of the photosphere, following magnetic field lines.
